intro: Brodiaea hyacinthina, commonly known as the Sierra Valley brodiaea, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Amaryllidaceae family and is characterized by its grass-like leaves and showy, bell-shaped flowers. The plant typically blooms in late spring to early summer, producing clusters of white or pale blue flowers. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in meadows and open woodlands. Due to habitat loss, it is considered a rare and endangered species in some regions.
